docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2. -- The first week of the Uruguayan revolt terminated today without the government's having been able to master the situation.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2. -- The first week of the Uruguayan revolt terminated today without the government's having been able to master the situation.
docs.abstract: torn RR tracks hinder army; more desertions reptd

headline.main: MONTEVIDEO FAILS TO MASTER REVOLT; First Week Ends With 8,000 Troops Still Seeking Battle With Rebel Force of 5,000.

docs.snippet: Business in the foreign exchange market last week was small, resulting in a narrow range in quotations. Trading was slowed down as banks and traders engaged only in routine transactions in anticipation of the decision in the gold-clause case,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Business in the foreign exchange market last week was small, resulting in a narrow range in quotations. Trading was slowed down as banks and traders engaged only in routine transactions in anticipation of the decision in the gold-clause case, expected to be handed down today.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; WEEK ENDED FEB. 2, 1935.

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 3. -- The second week of the Uruguayan revolt opened with indications of a sudden collapse of the rebels without serious fighting having occurred.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 3. -- The second week of the Uruguayan revolt opened with indications of a sudden collapse of the rebels without serious fighting having occurred.

headline.main: REVOLT IN URUGUAY IS NEAR COLLAPSE; Montevideo Reports Rebels Have Sent Peace Emissaries to Treat With Terra.

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4. -- Peace parleys between Uruguayan rebels and President Gabriel Terra became deadlocked today, and the rival armies lined up along a fifty-mile front paralleling the Rio Negro for a battle that is expected to decide the issue by...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4. -- Peace parleys between Uruguayan rebels and President Gabriel Terra became deadlocked today, and the rival armies lined up along a fifty-mile front paralleling the Rio Negro for a battle that is expected to decide the issue by force.
docs.abstract: rebels decline peace bid; 9th Infantry mutiny confirmed

headline.main: URUGUAYAN REBELS DECLINE PEACE BID; Armies Face Each Other Along Fifty-Mile Front as Parley Fails to End Revolt.

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The sharp increase in the foreign trade of the United States in 1934 extended to all grand divisions, according to an analysis by the Commerce Department.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The sharp increase in the foreign trade of the United States in 1934 extended to all grand divisions, according to an analysis by the Commerce Department.

headline.main: ALL LANDS BOUGHT MORE IN U.S. IN '34; Rise in Trade Extended to Every Grand Division, the Commerce Study Shows.

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5. -- The Uruguayan Government announced tonight that the rebel leader, Basilio Munoz, had been wounded by an aerial bombardment today and was being carried to Brazil by comrades.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5. -- The Uruguayan Government announced tonight that the rebel leader, Basilio Munoz, had been wounded by an aerial bombardment today and was being carried to Brazil by comrades.
docs.abstract: Munoz hurt; rebels move to unite; censorship

headline.main: URUGUAYAN AVIATORS BOMB REBEL LEADER; Basilio Munoz Reported to Be Seriously Wounded -- Revolutionaries Move to Unite.

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6. -- The Uruguayan Government reported today the capture of Osvaldo Olivera, second in command of the rebel army on the Rio Negro, whose chief, Basilio Munoz, was wounded by an aerial bombardment on Monday.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6. -- The Uruguayan Government reported today the capture of Osvaldo Olivera, second in command of the rebel army on the Rio Negro, whose chief, Basilio Munoz, was wounded by an aerial bombardment on Monday.
docs.abstract: O Olivera, rebel, taken; Brazilian censorship

headline.main: URUGUAY CAPTURES ONE OF REBEL CHIEFS; Reports That Rio Negro Army Is Surrounded and Probably Will Surrender Soon.
